intro: Thymus zattarellus, commonly known as the Corsican thyme, is a perennial herb native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, featuring small, gray-green leaves that are covered in fine hairs. Its flowers are usually pink to purple, forming dense clusters at the tips of the stems. This species is valued for its medicinal properties and is often used in herbal remedies.
